<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 429, 228, 445]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 447, 275, 462]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 462, 760, 478]]<|/det|>
Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 478, 806, 494]]<|/det|>
Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 494, 562, 509]]<|/det|>
Write your answer to each question in the space provided.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 510, 480, 525]]<|/det|>
Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 526, 361, 541]]<|/det|>
Do not write on any bar codes.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 541, 866, 572]]<|/det|>
If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 572, 480, 587]]<|/det|>
You should use a calculator where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 880, 618]]<|/det|>
You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 618, 856, 649]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 677, 220, 692]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 694, 384, 709]]<|/det|>
The total mark for this paper is 50.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 710, 728, 725]]<|/det|>
The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 81, 92, 100]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 81, 920, 119]]<|/det|>
A college uses two assessments, \(X\) and \(Y,\) when interviewing applicants for research posts at the college. These assessments have been used for a large number of applicants this year.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 128, 791, 149]]<|/det|>
The scores for a random sample of 9 applicants who took assessment \(X\) are as follows.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[225, 159, 771, 180]]<|/det|>
\[21.4\quad 24.6\quad 25.3\quad 22.7\quad 20.8\quad 21.5\quad 22.9\quad 21.3\quad 22.3\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 191, 801, 211]]<|/det|>
The scores for a random sample of 10 applicants who took assessment \(Y\) are as follows.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 222, 803, 242]]<|/det|>
\[20.9\quad 23.5\quad 24.8\quad 21.9\quad 23.4\quad 24.0\quad 23.8\quad 24.1\quad 25.1\quad 25.8\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 253, 920, 288]]<|/det|>
The interviewer believes that the population median score from assessment \(X\) is lower than the population median score from assessment \(Y.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 300, 920, 335]]<|/det|>
Carry out a Wilcoxon rank-sum test, at the \(1\%\) significance level, to test whether the interviewer's belief is supported by the data.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 316, 920, 335]]<|/det|>
<mark>[7]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 81, 92, 100]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 81, 920, 149]]<|/det|>
A rowing club has a large number of members. A random sample of 12 of these members is taken and the pulse rate, \(x\) beats per minute (bpm), of each is measured after a 30-minute training session. A \(98\%\) confidence interval for the population mean pulse rate, \(\mu\) bpm, is calculated from the sample as \(64.22 < \mu < 68.66\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 161, 146, 180]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 160, 410, 180]]<|/det|>
Find the values of \(\Sigma x\) and \(\Sigma x^2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 161, 920, 180]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 82, 92, 100]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 82, 920, 134]]<|/det|> There are three bus companies in a city. The council is investigating whether the buses reliably arrive at their destination on time. The results from random samples of buses from each company are summarised in the following table. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[141, 144, 892, 298]]<|/det|>
Bus company
ABCTotal
ArrivalEarly22221054
On time305242124
Late28261872
Total8010070250
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 310, 920, 329]]<|/det|> Test, at the \(5\%\) significance level, whether the reliability of buses is independent of bus company. [7] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 343, 920, 361]]<|/det|>
...... <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 375, 920, 393]]<|/det|> ...... <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 407, 920, 425]]<|/det|> ...... <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 439, 920, 457]]<|/det|> ...... <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 471, 920, 489]]<|/det|> ...... <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 503, 920, 521]]<|/det|> ...... <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 535, 920, 553]]<|/det|> ...... <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 567, 920, 585]]<|/det|> ...... <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 599, 920, 617]]<|/det|> ...... <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 631, 920, 649]]<|/det|> ...... <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 663, 920, 681]]<|/det|> ...... <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 695, 920, 713]]<|/det|> ...... <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 727, 920, 745]]<|/det|> ...... <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 759, 920, 777]]<|/det|> ...... <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 791, 920, 809]]<|/det|> ...... <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 823, 920, 841]]<|/det|> ...... <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 855, 920, 873]]<|/det|> ...... <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 887, 920, 905]]<|/det|> ...... <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 920, 920, 937]]<|/det|> ......

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 83, 97, 102]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 82, 702, 103]]<|/det|>
The random variable \(X\) has probability generating function \(\mathrm{G}_X(t)\) given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[423, 112, 576, 134]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm{G}_X(t) = ct(1 + t)^5,\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 146, 288, 165]]<|/det|>
where \(c\) is a constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 177, 146, 196]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 177, 311, 196]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(c\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 178, 917, 196]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 395, 143, 413]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 395, 346, 413]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(\mathrm{E}(X)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 395, 920, 413]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 81, 633, 101]]<|/det|>
The random variable \(Y\) is the sum of two independent values of \(X.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 114, 144, 133]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 114, 744, 133]]<|/det|>
Write down the probability generating function of \(Y\) and hence find \(\text{Var}(Y)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 114, 920, 133]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 151, 917, 170]]<|/det|>
<form>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 81, 94, 101]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 81, 763, 101]]<|/det|>
The continuous random variable \(X\) has cumulative distribution function F given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[351, 109, 645, 220]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm{F}\left(x\right) = \left\{ \begin{array}{ll}0 & x< 2,\\ \displaystyle \frac{\left(x - 2\right)^{2}}{12} & 2\leqslant x< 4,\\ 1 - \frac{\left(8 - x\right)^{2}}{24} & 4\leqslant x\leqslant 8,\\ 1 & x > 8. \end{array} \right.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 237, 146, 256]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 237, 601, 256]]<|/det|>
Sketch the graph of the probability density function of \(X\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 238, 917, 256]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 612, 146, 630]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 612, 248, 630]]<|/det|>
Find \(\mathrm{E}(X)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 612, 920, 630]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 82, 144, 101]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 82, 556, 101]]<|/det|>
Find the exact value of the interquartile range of \(X.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 82, 920, 101]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 81, 94, 100]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 81, 920, 149]]<|/det|>
Seva is investigating the lengths of the tails of adult wallabies in two regions of Australia, \(X\) and \(Y.\) He chooses a random sample of 50 adult wallabies from region \(X\) and records the lengths, \(x\mathrm{cm},\) of their tails. He also chooses a random sample of 40 adult wallabies from region \(Y\) and records the lengths, \(y\mathrm{cm},\) of their tails. His results are summarised as follows.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 159, 767, 180]]<|/det|>
\[\Sigma x = 1080\qquad \Sigma x^{2} = 23480\qquad \Sigma y = 940\qquad \Sigma y^{2} = 22 220\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 191, 803, 211]]<|/det|>
It cannot be assumed that the population variances of the two distributions are the same.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 222, 146, 241]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 222, 920, 257]]<|/det|>
Find a \(90\%\) confidence interval for the difference between the population mean lengths of the tails of adult wallabies in regions \(X\) and \(Y. \)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 240, 920, 257]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 81, 920, 120]]<|/det|>
The population mean lengths of the tails of adult wallabies in regions \(X\) and \(Y\) are \(\mu_{X}\) cm and \(\mu_{Y}\) cm respectively.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 129, 148, 147]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 128, 920, 167]]<|/det|>
Test, at the \(10\%\) significance level, the null hypothesis \(\mu_{Y} - \mu_{X} = 1.1\) against the alternative hypothesis \(\mu_{Y} - \mu_{X} > 1.1\). State your conclusion in the context of the question.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 147, 920, 165]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 114, 920, 147]]<|/det|>
